questions.text: Which of the following structures marked in the below image gives rise to the heart in an adult? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. D

 

Explanation:

 

The above image is of the embryo and the structure which gives rise to the heart in an adult is the heart bulge (Cardiac cushion)- a structure marked as ‘D’.

 

The marked structure in the given diagram are

 

A - Head

B – Primitive lens

C – Pharyngeal arches

D – Heart bulge

E – liver bulge

F – Limb bud

G – Leg Bud

H – Tail

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E (Liver bulge): Does not develop into the heart.

 

Option C. F (Limb bud): Develops into limbs, not cardiac structures.

 

Option D. A (Head): Develops into head structures, not the heart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Detailed Developmental stages:

 

1. Early Formation:

 

  • In the third week of embryonic development, paired strands of lateral plate mesoderm called the "cardiogenic mesoderm" or "cardiogenic fields" begin to form in the anterior region of the embryonic disc.
  • These strands coalesce in the midline of the embryo to form the "cardiac crescent" or "heart bulge".

 

2. Heart Tube Formation:

 

  • By the beginning of the fourth week, as the embryo undergoes lateral folding, the cardiac crescent fuses in the midline to form a straight heart tube. This tube comprises an outer myocardial layer and an inner endocardial layer with a cardiac jelly in between.

 

3. Differential Growth and Looping:

 

  • Soon after its formation, the heart tube undergoes differential growth which leads it to elongate. This elongation and subsequent bending result in the process called "cardiac looping", where the tube forms a C-shaped loop.
  • The original straight tube's sections become discernible regions: the sinus venosus, atrium, ventricle, bulbus cordis, and truncus arteriosus (from caudal to cranial).

 

4. Partitioning:

 

  • The single atrium and ventricle of the looped heart tube undergo partitioning (septation) to form the four chambers of the mature heart.
  • The atrioventricular canal, initially a single passage between the atrium and ventricle, is also divided.

 

5. Formation of Outflow Tracts:

 

  • The bulbus cordis and truncus arteriosus undergo remodeling to give rise to the roots and initial portions of the aorta and pulmonary artery.

 

6. Incorporation of Sinus Venosus:

 

  • Initially, the sinus venosus, which receives all the embryonic venous return, opens into the right side of the primitive atrium. With time, the right side of the sinus venosus is incorporated into the forming right atrium, giving rise to the smooth part of its interior (sinus venarum).

 

7. Valve Formation:

 

  • Valves form from endocardial cushions in the atrioventricular canal and from additional cushions in the truncus arteriosus and bulbus cordis.

 

8. Maturation:

 

  • By the end of the embryonic period (8th week), the heart looks much like it will at birth, though further growth and maturation will occur during the fetal period.

questions.text: Identify the structure in the following histological image: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Glomerulus

 

The above histology image shows the glomerulus of a nephron.

 

Glomerulus is a tuft of capillaries located within Bowman's capsule in the renal cortex of the kidney. Here are the key histological features of the glomerulus:

 

  • Capillary Endothelium: The innermost layer of the glomerulus consists of fenestrated endothelial cells. These fenestrations or pores allow plasma (minus the larger proteins) to move from the blood into Bowman's space.
  • Basement Membrane: Surrounding the endothelial cells is the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). It is a specialized extracellular matrix made up of type IV collagen, laminin, proteoglycans, and other glycoproteins. The GBM serves as a filter, preventing the passage of large proteins and cells but allowing smaller molecules to pass through.
  • Podocytes: These specialized epithelial cells cover the outer surface of the glomerular capillaries. They have foot processes called "pedicels" which interdigitate with one another, leaving filtration slits between them. The slit diaphragm, formed by intercellular junctions between adjacent pedicels, provides an additional barrier to the filtration of plasma proteins.
  • Mesangial Cells: Located between the capillaries of the glomerulus, mesangial cells have phagocytic activity and help in the structural support of the capillaries. They can also contract, thus regulating the blood flow through the glomerulus. Additionally, mesangial cells produce extracellular matrix components.
  • Juxtaglomerular Cells: These specialized smooth muscle cells are found in the afferent arteriole at the point of entry into the glomerulus. They secrete renin, a crucial enzyme in the renin-angiotensin system which regulates blood pressure.
  • Macula Densa: Although not a part of the glomerulus, the macula densa is closely related. It is a group of tall, closely packed cells in the distal convoluted tubule that detect changes in the sodium chloride levels in the filtrate and communicate with the juxtaglomerular cells to regulate renin secretion.
  • Bowman's Capsule: This is a double-layered capsule that surrounds the glomerulus. The inner layer, or visceral layer, is composed of podocytes. The outer layer, or parietal layer, is made up of a simple squamous epithelium. Between these two layers is the Bowman's space, into which the filtrate from the blood accumulates before moving into the renal tubules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leydig Cells, also known as interstitial cells of Leydig, are present in the interstitial connective between seminiferous tubules.

 

The testis contains numerous seminiferous tubules separated by connective tissue in between.

 

Seminiferous tubules are lined by several spermatogonia cells, which produce spermatozoa, and Sertoli (sustentacular) cells, which have a supportive function.The connective tissue in between the tubules is made up of Leydig cells, collagen fibers, fibroblasts, macrophages, mast cells, blood vessels, and lymphatics. Leydig cells are large, round, or polyhedral cells with eccentric nuclei. They are lightly stained and often have a foamy appearance. They secrete testosterone upon stimulation by luteinizing hormone from the anterior pituitary.

 

The image below shows seminiferous tubules and Leydig cells

 

 

Option B: Islets of Langerhans makes up the endocrine part of the pancreas.

 

Islets are characterized by secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers and contain numerous fenestrated capillaries. There is a delicate capsule around each islet. The islet cells are paler than the surrounding exocrine cells, as they have less rough endoplasmic reticulum.

 

﻿﻿ The islet of Langerhans is mainly composed of three types of cells:

 

  • α or A cells - located peripherally and secrete glucagon
  • β or B cells - located centrally and produce insulin
  • δ or D cells - scattered between beta cells and secrete somatostatin

 

The image given below shows the islets of Langerhans

 

 

Option C: The thymic medulla contains fewer lymphocytes than the cortex, and the epithelial cells (E) located here have different morphology and function. The most characteristic feature of the medulla in humans is the presence of thymic (Hassall) corpuscles (H). These are of variable size and contain aggregates of thymic epithelial cells releasing many cytokines important within the medullary microenvironment, especially for dendritic cell activity and for the differentiation of regulatory T cells.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The glomerulus consists of a network of capillaries encased within Bowman's capsule, playing a key role in blood filtration.

questions.text: What is the vertebral level of the Green marked structure in the image in anatomical position? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coccyx

 

The marked structure in the image is the ischial spine. In anatomical position, the ischial spine is located at the level of the coccyx. This is important in various medical procedures, including the pudendal nerve block, commonly used in obstetrics and gynecology. The ischial spine serves as a significant landmark for these procedures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L4: Incorrect. The L4 vertebra is located much higher in the vertebral column, around the lower back region, and is not associated with the ischial spine.

 

Option B. L4-L5: Incorrect. This option refers to the intervertebral disc space between L4 and L5, which is also in the lower back but not related to the pelvic region or ischial spine.

 

Option C. S3-S5: Incorrect. Although the ischial spine can be aligned with these sacral vertebrae in certain positions like lithotomy (during childbirth), but here the question is about anatomical position so this is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ischial spine in anatomical position aligns with the coccyx, serving as an important landmark for various medical procedures.

choices.text: Inferior vena cava

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman undergoes surgery for a hiatal hernia. During the operation, the surgeon needs to identify the structures passing through the diaphragm to avoid complications. The surgeon points out an important structure that passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm.  Which of the following structures passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Inferior vena cava

 

Explanation:

 

The inferior vena cava (IVC) is the major vein that returns deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body to the right atrium of the heart. It passes through the diaphragm via the caval foramen, which is situated within the central tendon of the diaphragm at the level of the eighth thoracic vertebra (T8). The central tendon ensures that the IVC remains patent during respiration, allowing for consistent blood flow to the heart. The diaphragm has three primary openings: the aortic hiatus at T12, the esophageal hiatus at T10, and the caval foramen at T8. The IVC specifically traverses through the caval foramen, unlike other structures that pass through different diaphragmatic apertures. The esophagus passes through the esophageal hiatus, the aorta traverses the aortic hiatus, and the sympathetic chain passes through minor apertures crossing the crura of the diaphragm.

 

Other Options

 

A. Esophagus: The esophagus passes through the esophageal hiatus located at the T10 level of the diaphragm. This hiatus is surrounded by muscle fibers, which help prevent reflux of gastric contents into the esophagus, and it is distinct from the caval foramen through which the IVC passes.

 

C. Aorta: The aorta, the major artery carrying blood from the heart to the rest of the body, passes through the aortic hiatus at the T12 level. This hiatus is located posteriorly and is not associated with the central tendon of the diaphragm, setting it apart from the route taken by the IVC.

 

D. Greater splanchnic nerve: This nerve, along with other splanchnic nerves, passes through minor apertures that cross the crura of the diaphragm. These small openings are separate from the major diaphragmatic openings and accommodate nerve fibers rather than major blood vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diaphragm contains three major anatomical openings: the aortic hiatus (T12), esophageal hiatus (T10), and caval foramen (T8). The inferior vena cava specifically passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm via the caval foramen, ensuring uninterrupted blood flow from the lower body to the heart.

questions.text: Examine the histological section provided. Which type of cartilage is shown in the image?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. White fibrocartilage

 

The given image shows prominent collagen fibers arranged in bundles with intervening rows of chondrocytes. This is suggestive of white fibrocartilage.

 

Microscopy of fibrocartilage shows the following:

 

  • Chondrocytes- Round in shape (in tendons they are flattened and elongated)
  • Ground tissue with collagen fibers- Type I collagen fibers
  • Absence of perichondrium

 

Note - White fibrocartilage is dense with collagen fibers (primarily type I collagen), which gives a great tensile strength. It is found in intervertebral discs, pubic symphysis, menisci of the knee, and places where tendons insert into bones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-articular hyaline cartilage: It's a type of hyaline cartilage not involved in joint articulations. The matrix contains a moderate amount of collagen fibers, predominantly type II collagen, making it tough but somewhat flexible. It is found in the respiratory tract (including the trachea, bronchi, and nasal cartilages), growth plates of bones, and the anterior aspect of ribs (costal cartilages).

 

Option B. Articular hyaline cartilage: It is similar in composition to non-articular hyaline cartilage, but specifically lines the surfaces of bones in synovial joints. It covers the ends of bones in synovial joints such as the knee, shoulder, and hip.

 

Option C. Yellow cartilage (Elastic cartilage): It contains elastic fibers and collagen fibers, mainly type II collagen. The elastic fibers give it more flexibility than hyaline cartilage. It is found in the ear pinna (auricle), epiglottis, and auditory (Eustachian) tubes.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Fundus and body of Gall bladder

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an anterior relation of the third part of the duodenum? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fundus and body of Gall bladder

 

Explanation:

 

The fundus and body of the gallbladder are not typically considered anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum. The gallbladder is situated more to the right and superior to the duodenum, so it is not directly in front of it.

 

Note - The junction of the first and second parts of the duodenum lies posterior to the neck of the gallbladder. The anterior relations of the third segment of the duodenum comprise the Superior mesenteric vessels, the Root of the mesentery, and Loops of the jejunum

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Superior mesenteric vessels: The superior mesenteric vessels, which include the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and superior mesenteric vein (SMV), are anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum. The SMA runs just posterior to the third part of the duodenum, and the SMV is typically located to the right of the SMA and also in front of the duodenum.

 

Option B) Loops of jejunum:  Loops of the jejunum, which are part of the small intestine, can lie anterior to the third part of the duodenum. The small intestine, including the jejunum, is positioned in the abdominal cavity, and its loops can be found in close proximity to the duodenum.

 

Option C) Root of mesentery: The root of the mesentery is an extension of the peritoneum that connects the small intestine (including the jejunum and ileum) to the posterior abdominal wall. It passes in front of the third part of the duodenum as it continues to the jejunum and ileum. Therefore, it is an anterior relation of the third part of the duodenum.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Inferior thyroid artery is the branch of which of the following? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Thyrocervical trunk

 

Explanation:

 

The inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk, which is a branch of the subclavian artery's first part. The inferior thyroid artery ascends anterior to the medial border of the scalenus anterior, then turns medially just below the sixth cervical transverse process and descends on longus colli to the thyroid gland's lower border.

 

 

The relationships between the terminal branches and the recurrent laryngeal nerve are highly variable and have significant surgical implications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External Carotid Artery: The external carotid artery supplies most of the structures in the neck, face, scalp, and the upper part of the skull. This artery has several branches, including the superior thyroid, lingual, facial, maxillary, and superficial temporal arteries, among others. While it does supply areas around the thyroid, especially through its superior thyroid branch, it is not the origin of the inferior thyroid artery.

 

Option B. Internal Carotid Artery: The internal carotid artery has no branches in the neck. Instead, it moves upward to supply the brain and eyes. It's essential for cerebral circulation and plays a crucial role in supplying blood to the brain.

 

Option D. Lingual Artery: The lingual artery is a branch of the external carotid artery. It supplies the muscles and mucosa of the tongue. Given its role and location, it is not involved in supplying the thyroid gland or associated structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thyrocervical trunk is a short branch of the subclavian artery, and it supplies numerous structures in the neck. The branches of the thyrocervical trunk are the inferior thyroid artery, the ascending cervical artery, and the transverse cervical artery (which can further divide into superficial and deep branches). The inferior thyroid artery, which arises from the thyrocervical trunk, mainly supplies the thyroid and parathyroid glands.

choices.text: The right adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape.
The left adrenal gland is closely related with the tail of pancreas and spleen.
The adrenal are yellow on gross appearance.
The adrenal are retroperitoneal in location.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the anatomy of the adrenal glands?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The right adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape.

 

 

  • The right adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape: This statement is false. The right adrenal gland is actually pyramidal in shape. The left adrenal gland is semi-lunar (crescent-shaped) in shape. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The left adrenal gland is closely related with the tail of pancreas and spleen: This statement is true. The left adrenal gland is anatomically positioned near the tail of the pancreas and the spleen.

 

Option C. The adrenal are yellow on gross appearance: This statement is true. The adrenal glands have a yellowish appearance on gross examination due to their rich lipid content.

 

Option D. The adrenal are retroperitoneal in location: This statement is true. The adrenal glands, like the kidneys, are retroperitoneal, meaning they are located behind the peritoneum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The right adrenal gland is pyramidal in shape, while the left adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes in close proximity to the area marked by the arrow in the given image? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Middle meningeal artery

 

Explanation:

 

The middle meningeal artery (MMA) is a branch of the maxillary artery (a terminal branch of the external carotid artery). The MMA enters the middle cranial fossa by passing through the foramen spinosum. After entering the skull, it courses laterally to the pterion.

 

Given the proximity of the MMA to the pterion, trauma to this region can lead to an extradural (epidural) hematoma if the MMA is torn. This is because the MMA runs just deep to the pterion, between the skull and the dura mater.

 

This makes the MMA the artery most closely related to the pterion, and a fracture at the pterion can lead to rupture of this artery.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal carotid artery:

 

  • The internal carotid artery (ICA) is a major artery that supplies blood to the brain. It arises from the common carotid artery and enters the cranial cavity through the carotid canal.
  • While the ICA does travel inside the skull and provides blood to the brain, it doesn't have a direct relationship with the pterion. It is more medial in its course.

 

Option C. Anterior cerebral artery:

 

  • The anterior cerebral artery is one of the terminal branches of the internal carotid artery. It supplies the medial and superior parts of the brain.
  • Though it's an essential artery for cerebral circulation, it doesn't have a direct relationship with the pterion, as its course and distribution are more medial.

 

Option D. Deep temporal artery:

 

  • The deep temporal arteries are branches of the maxillary artery that ascend between the temporalis muscle and the side of the skull.
  • They supply the temporalis muscle, and while they are in the vicinity of the pterion, they are not as closely related as the middle meningeal artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterion is an H shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

 

  • Frontal bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Parietal bone.

 

Given that it rests across the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and the lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere, it is a significant structure. Since the bone in this region is fragile, any injury could cause the middle meningeal artery to burst, resulting in an extradural hematoma.

choices.text: Physiological hernia failing to go back

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the embryological basis for the formation of an omphalocele? ( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Physiological hernia failing to go back

 

  • Omphalocele is characterized by the herniation of abdominal viscera through an enlarged umbilical ring.
  • Amnion protects the viscera, which may include the liver, small and large intestines, stomach, spleen, or gallbladder.
  • The defect is caused by the bowel's failure to return to the body cavity after its physiological herniation between the sixth and tenth weeks.

 

 

Omphalocele is associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and with increased levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive length of the intestine: During early embryonic development, the intestines do grow at a rapid pace, leading to temporary herniation of the midgut into the umbilical cord around the 6th week. This is called physiological midgut herniation. The intestines then rotate and usually return into the abdominal cavity by the 10th week. It's not the excessive length of the intestine itself that causes omphalocele; rather, it's the failure of the intestines (and sometimes other organs) to return to the abdominal cavity.

 

Option C. Herniation of liver: While the liver can indeed be one of the organs present in an omphalocele, its herniation is not the primary cause of omphalocele. Instead, it is a consequence of the failure of the physiological hernia to return to the abdominal cavity. In larger omphaloceles, the liver is more commonly seen as part of the herniated content.

 

Option D. Herniation of umbilicus: This option is not precise. The umbilicus itself is not what herniates in omphalocele. Instead, it's through the region of the umbilicus that the intestines and possibly other organs herniate out into the umbilical cord during development. If they fail to return to the abdomen, an omphalocele forms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalocele is primarily caused by the failure of the physiological hernia of the midgut to return to the abdominal cavity during fetal development, not merely by the excessive length of the intestine or specific organ herniation.

choices.text: Lower limb paralysis

questions.text: What will occur if the area marked in the sagittal section of the brain below is affected? (AIIMS NOV  2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Aphasia

 

Explanation:

 

The marked area in the sagittal section of the brain corresponds to the frontal lobe, specifically the Broca’s area, which is primarily responsible for speech production. Damage to this area results in aphasia, specifically Broca's aphasia. This type of aphasia is characterized by difficulty in forming complete sentences and in speaking fluently, although comprehension generally remains intact. It is a non-fluent aphasia where individuals know what they want to say but struggle to communicate it effectively.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A (Lower limb paralysis) is incorrect because this symptom is typically associated with damage to the motor cortex, not the Broca’s area.
  • Option B (Visual agnosia) is incorrect as visual agnosia results from damage to the visual processing areas, typically located in the occipital and temporal lobes, not the frontal lobe.
  • Option D (Diplopia) also does not result from damage to Broca's area but rather from issues within the brainstem or cranial nerves that control eye movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Broca's area, located in the frontal lobe of the brain, is crucial for speech production. Damage to this area can lead to aphasia, particularly affecting the ability to speak fluently while sparing comprehension.

questions.text: Bleeding as shown in the image is due to which of the following vessels?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bridging veins

 

The image demonstrating a bleed over the arachnoid layer but beneath the dura suggests a subdural hemorrhage. It is most commonly caused by the shearing of cortical bridging veins.

 

A subdural hemorrhage is a type of intracranial hemorrhage, which is bleeding within the skull. It occurs when blood accumulates between the dura mater (the tough outermost layer of the meninges) and the arachnoid mater (the middle layer of the meninges) surrounding the brain.

 

Subdural hemorrhages are usually caused by trauma to the head, such as falls or motor vehicle accidents, which can tear the veins that bridge the dura and arachnoid layers. The bleeding can create pressure on the brain, leading to neurological symptoms such as headaches, confusion, dizziness, seizures, and in severe cases, coma or death.

 

The symptoms of a subdural hemorrhage can develop immediately or may take hours or even days to appear, depending on the severity of the bleeding. In some cases, a small subdural hemorrhage may resolve on its own without treatment, while larger or more severe bleeds may require surgery to relieve pressure on the brain and stop the bleeding.

 

Factors that can increase the risk of a subdural hemorrhage include advanced age, alcohol or drug abuse, blood-thinning medications, and medical conditions that affect blood clotting or increase the risk of falls. Early recognition and treatment of a subdural hemorrhage can improve outcomes and prevent complications.

 

Dx:- Non-Contrast CT is the investigation of choice.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Middle meningeal artery rupture would result in an extradural hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Lenticulostriate artery would lead to an intraparenchymal hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Vertebral artery dissection leads to subarachnoid hemorrhage or sometimes intraparenchymal hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognition of a subdural hemorrhage is crucial following head trauma, especially in individuals at higher risk such as the elderly, those on anticoagulation therapy, or those with a history of alcohol abuse. Immediate medical evaluation is vital to manage the condition effectively and mitigate potential severe outcomes.

questions.text: What is the main action of the muscle marked below? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Elevation

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle marked in the image is the temporalis and its main action is elevation of the mandible.

 

Other actions are:

 

  • ﻿﻿It helps in the side-to-side grinding movements of the mandible.
  • ﻿﻿The posterior fibres which are horizontal, help in the retraction of the mandible.

 

The muscles of mastication are a group of four muscles that are responsible for the movements of the jaw during chewing (mastication). These muscles include:

 

Together, these muscles work to elevate and depress the mandible, move it side to side, and protrude it forward. They are important for chewing, speaking, and swallowing. Dysfunction of these muscles can result in temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorders and other oral health problems.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Depression: This action is not associated with the temporalis muscle. Depression of the mandible, which involves opening the jaw, is primarily accomplished by the digastric muscle and, to some extent, by the lateral pterygoid muscle.

 

Option C. Protrusion: Protrusion refers to pushing the jaw forward. This action is chiefly performed by the lateral pterygoid muscle, not the temporalis.

 

Option D. Retraction: While the posterior fibers of the temporalis muscle do assist in retraction of the mandible, pulling it backward, it is not the primary action of the entire muscle. The main retractor of the jaw is the posterior part of the temporalis muscle alongside the digastric muscle (posterior belly).

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Fibres of the given structure originate from? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hippocampus

 

Explanation:

 

The given structure is the fornix and its fibres arise from the hippocampus.

 

The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of white matter fibers that connects the hippocampus to other regions of the brain, including the mammillary bodies, thalamus, and septal nuclei. The fibers of the fornix arise from the hippocampus, which is involved in the formation and consolidation of memories, and then project through the fornix to other parts of the limbic system. Dysfunction of the fornix and hippocampus can result in memory impairments, as seen in conditions such as Alzheimer's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amygdala: The amygdala is a small almond-shaped structure located deep within the temporal lobes of the brain. It is involved in processing emotions, especially fear and emotional memory. While the amygdala does have connections to the limbic system, it is not a direct source of fibers for the fornix. However, it does interact with the hippocampus and other limbic structures.

 

Option B. Mammillary Body: The mammillary bodies are a pair of small, round structures located on the undersurface of the brain, specifically in the diencephalon. They are closely connected to the hippocampus and are considered part of the limbic system. The fornix sends fibers to and receives fibers from the mammillary bodies, facilitating the flow of information within the limbic circuit.

 

Option C. Caudate Nucleus: The caudate nucleus is a component of the basal ganglia and is involved in motor control and cognitive functions. While it interacts with some limbic structures, it is not a primary source of fornix fibers. Instead, it has connections with other regions involved in motor control and reward processing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hippocampus is a critical structure within the limbic system that plays a central role in memory formation and spatial navigation. It is the primary source of fibers that make up the fornix. The fornix carries information from the hippocampus to other limbic structures, including the mammillary bodies and the anterior thalamic nuclei, as well as to the septal nuclei and the cingulate gyrus.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented with fever and massive splenomegaly. On palpation, the spleen was 15 cm and directed obliquely when measured from the right iliac fossa. Which of the following structures prevent the vertical and downward descent of the spleen? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Phrenicocolic ligament

 

  • The downward movement of the spleen is naturally prevented by the phrenicocolic ligament, which does not attach to the spleen itself but supports its anterior end.
  • This ligament is a horizontal fold of peritoneum that extends from the splenic flexure of the colon to the diaphragm, opposite of the 11th rib in the midaxillary line. The phrenicocolic ligament also limits the upper end of the left paracolic gutter.
  • In cases where the spleen becomes enlarged, the phrenicocolic ligament and splenic flexure of the colon restrict its downward displacement. This enlargement typically occurs towards the right iliac fossa, causing the spleen to be directed obliquely.
  • By supporting the anterior end of the spleen, the phrenicocolic ligament plays an important role in preventing its excessive movement and displacement within the abdominal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lienorenal ligament: This ligament connects the hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney and contains the tail of the pancreas and vessels that supply the spleen. It helps to hold the spleen in its anatomical position, preventing it from moving medially.

 

Option B. Gastrosplenic ligament: This is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the greater curvature of the stomach to the hilum of the spleen. It contains the short gastric vessels and contributes to the attachment of the spleen to the stomach. It prevents the spleen from moving too far posteriorly.

 

Option D. Lienophrenic ligament: The term "lienophrenic ligament" isn't a standard anatomical term. The spleen does have ligamentous connections with the diaphragm, but these are typically referred to as part of the lienorenal and gastrosplenic ligaments. Therefore, this option might be a misnomer or less commonly used terminology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phrenicocolic ligament extends from the left colic (splenic) flexure of the colon to the diaphragm. It's positioned to the left side of the abdomen and is an important anatomical landmark. It acts as a supportive structure, supporting the left colic flexure and acting as a barrier. Importantly, it prevents the downward and medial displacement of the spleen, especially when the spleen enlarges, as in cases of splenomegaly.

 

Splenic ligaments and their attachments:

questions.text: At which level does the nerve supply for the marked structure arise? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Red nucleus

 

Explanation:

 

The medial rectus muscle is the one highlighted in the provided CT picture. The oculomotor nerve, whose nucleus is located at the level of the superior colliculus adjacent to the red nucleus, supplies the medial rectus.

 

The nuclear complex from which the oculomotor nerve arises consists of:

 

  • Several groups of large motor neurons are collectively called the oculomotor nucleus. The motor neuron groups of the oculomotor nucleus innervate, in dorsoventral order, the ipsilateral inferior rectus, inferior oblique, and medial rectus. A medially placed column of cells innervates the contralateral superior rectus.
  • Smaller preganglionic parasympathetic neurons called the Edinger-Westphal preganglionic nucleus

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subthalamic nuclei: The subthalamic nucleus is part of the diencephalon and is closely associated with the basal ganglia circuitry. It plays a role in motor control. It's not directly associated with the oculomotor nerve's origin.

 

Option C. Decussation of pyramidal tract: The decussation of the pyramidal tract (motor fibers) occurs in the lower medulla oblongata, well below the level of the oculomotor nerve's origin. This is where the majority of motor fibers from one hemisphere cross to the opposite side.

 

Option D. Olivary nucleus: The olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata and is primarily associated with the coordination of motor tasks. Again, it's located caudally relative to the oculomotor nerve's origin in the midbrain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oculomotor nerve (CN III) arises from the anterior aspect of the midbrain, at the level of the superior colliculus. Its nucleus is situated ventral to the cerebral aqueduct and in close proximity to the red nucleus. Hence, the oculomotor nerve is often associated with the level of the red nucleus in the midbrain. It exits the midbrain medial to the cerebral peduncle.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman visits her obstetrician for her first prenatal check-up. She is curious about her baby’s development, particularly the formation of vital organs. During the discussion, she asks when the baby’s heart begins to beat. The obstetrician explains that the early heart starts beating at a specific point in early embryonic development. In which week of development does the heart begin to beat?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Fourth week

 

Explanation:

 

The heart begins to beat in the fourth week of embryonic development. During this period, the heart starts as a simple linear tube, which undergoes looping and structural changes that eventually lead to the formation of the heart’s chambers. By the end of the fourth week, the heart has started to contract and pump blood, although the full four-chamber structure is not yet fully developed. This early beating is crucial for establishing blood circulation and supporting the growing embryo.

 

Other Options

 

A. Second week: During the second week, the embryo is still undergoing basic formation processes, including the development of the bilaminar disc and implantation. The heart has not yet formed or started beating at this stage, making this an incorrect answer.

 

C. Sixth week: By the sixth week, the heart is further developing its chambers and valves, but it has already been beating for about two weeks. This period is more focused on the refinement of the heart structure rather than the initiation of its beating.

 

D. Eighth week: By the eighth week, the heart is significantly more developed with distinct chambers and functioning valves. The heart has been beating for several weeks by this point, supporting more complex circulatory patterns in the embryo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The heart begins to beat during the fourth week of embryonic development, starting as a simple tube that undergoes looping and structural changes to eventually form the chambers of the heart. Early cardiac contractions are essential for establishing blood circulation, even before the heart is fully formed with four chambers.

questions.text: Which of the following finger has two dorsal interossei muscles? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Middle finger

 

Explanation:

 

The middle finger has two dorsal interossei muscles flanking it. One is positioned between the index and middle fingers, and the other is positioned between the middle and ring fingers.

 

This anatomical configuration allows the middle finger to be abducted in both directions: towards the index finger and towards the ring finger.

 

 

The dorsal interossei muscles are four bipennate muscles located between the metacarpal bones in the hand. They are named "dorsal" because they are located on the dorsum (back) of the hand, and "interossei" means between bones. Their main action is to abduct the fingers away from the axial line, which runs down the center of the third (middle) finger.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Index finger: This finger has one dorsal interosseous muscle which abducts the index finger away from the middle finger.

 

Option B. Little finger: The little finger also has one dorsal interosseous muscle. This muscle abducts the little finger away from the ring finger.

 

Option D. Ring finger: The ring finger has one dorsal interosseous muscle which abducts it away from the little finger.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Fibers from the marked structure end in which of the following areas of the thalamus?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior nucleus

 

The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is where the fibres from the mamillary body, which is the structure seen in the above figure, terminate.

 

The third ventricle's floor is made up of two tiny, hemispherical, pea-sized eminences called mammillary bodies, which are arranged side by side. The anterior thalamic nucleus receives fibres from the medial mammillary nucleus.

 

The anterior thalamic nuclei have 3 subdivisions -anteroventral nucleus, anteromedial nucleus, and anterodorsal nucleus.

 

  • Major input: Mammillothalamic tract from the mammillary nuclei of the hypothalamus.
  • Major cortical output: Anterior limbic area, cingulate, and the parahippocampal gyrus
  • Major function:
    • Regulation of alertness and attention
    • Acquisition of memory

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior nucleus: The posterior nuclear group, also known as the pulvinar, is the largest nuclear group in the thalamus. It is involved in the integration of visual, auditory, and somatosensory information. The mammillothalamic tract does not terminate in the posterior nucleus.

 

Option B. Reticular nucleus: The reticular nucleus of the thalamus surrounds the lateral aspect of the thalamus and serves as a modulator of information transfer between different parts of the thalamus and the cerebral cortex. It primarily functions to regulate the activity of relay nuclei in the thalamus. While it plays an important role in modulating thalamic function, the mammillothalamic tract does not primarily terminate here.

 

Option D. Ventral Lateral nucleus: The ventral lateral nucleus is one of the principal relay nuclei of the thalamus that receives inputs from the cerebellum and the basal ganglia and projects to the primary motor cortex. It is involved in the coordination and planning of movements. The mammillothalamic tract does not terminate in the ventral lateral nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior nuclear group of the thalamus is involved in emotional tone and recent memory. Fibers from the mammillary bodies, via the mammillothalamic tract, terminate in the anterior nuclei of the thalamus. The connection between the mammillary bodies and the anterior thalamic nucleus is a crucial part of the Papez circuit.

questions.text: Which of the following structures of brachial plexus do not give branches? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Divisions

 

Explanation:

 

The divisions in the brachial plexus do not give any branches.

 

However, the roots, trunks, and cords of the brachial plexus give out direct branches.

 

The brachial plexus is a complex network of nerves that originates from the ventral rami of the fifth cervical to the first thoracic spinal nerves (C5-T1). The brachial plexus is typically organized into five stages: roots, trunks, divisions, cords, and terminal branches.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Roots: The roots of the brachial plexus are the five ventral rami (C5-T1) that serve as the origin of the brachial plexus. These roots give off several branches:

 

  • C5 root can contribute to the dorsal scapular nerve.
  • C5 and C6 roots together give rise to the upper trunk, but before they merge, they can give off the nerve to the subclavius muscle (from C5 and C6).
  • C8 and T1 roots can contribute to the long thoracic nerve along with C7 root.

 

Option B. Cords: The cords are named based on their position relative to the axillary artery: lateral, medial, and posterior cords.

 

  • The lateral cord gives branches like the lateral pectoral nerve.
  • The medial cord gives branches like the medial pectoral, medial cutaneous nerve of arm, and medial cutaneous nerve of forearm.
  • The posterior cord provides branches like the upper subscapular, thoracodorsal, and lower subscapular nerves.

 

Option C. Trunks: There are three trunks in the brachial plexus: upper, middle, and lower.

 

  • The upper trunk is formed by the union of C5 and C6 roots and gives off the suprascapular nerve and the nerve to the omohyoid muscle.
  • The middle and lower trunks usually do not give any significant branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each trunk divides into two divisions: an anterior division and a posterior division. The divisions do not provide any branches.

questions.text: Reticular fibres are not present in which of the following structures? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Thymus

 

Explanation:

 

Reticular fibres are not present in the thymus. The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ involved in the development and maturation of T lymphocytes (T cells) and does not contain a significant amount of reticular fibers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lymph Node: Lymph nodes contain reticular fibers within their structure. Reticular fibers in lymph nodes create a network that supports immune cells, such as lymphocytes and macrophages, as they filter and process lymphatic fluid.

 

Option C. Bone Marrow: Reticular fibers are found in the bone marrow. They contribute to the framework of the bone marrow, supporting blood-forming cells and various hematopoietic elements involved in blood cell production.

 

Option D. Spleen: Reticular fibers are present in the spleen. Similar to lymph nodes, the spleen contains reticular fibers that support immune cells and help filter blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reticular fibres:

 

A form of connective tissue fibre known as reticular fibres, reticular fibres, or reticulin is made of type III collagen released by reticular cells. Crosslinking reticular fibres create a delicate meshwork (reticulin). Soft tissues like the liver, bone marrow, and the tissues and organs of the lymphatic system benefit from the support provided by this network.

 

They differ from type I collagen fibres in that, they are finer and are arranged in the form of a network (reticulum). The fibres appear black in colour on staining with silver impregnation. Due to this affinity to silver salts, they are also known as argentophil fibres.

questions.text: Which of the following anatomical landmarks is not commonly used for identifying the facial nerve trunk during parotid surgery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inferior belly of omohyoid muscle

 

The omohyoid muscle is a thin, flat muscle in the anterior neck, and it has no direct anatomical relation to the facial nerve trunk. Therefore, it is not used as a landmark to identify the facial nerve trunk during surgeries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrograde dissection from distal branch: This involves tracing the facial nerve branches from their more distal and superficial positions back towards their origin at the main trunk of the facial nerve. This is a common technique used by surgeons, especially when there is difficulty locating the main trunk due to factors like inflammation, previous surgery, or anatomical variations.

 

Option B. Tragal pointer: It is a small cartilaginous projection at the anterior margin of the external auditory meatus, from the tragus of the ear. The main trunk of the facial nerve typically lies about 1 cm deep and slightly inferior to the tragal pointer, making it a reliable landmark to locate the facial nerve trunk during parotid gland surgeries.

 

Option D. Posterior belly of digastric: The posterior belly of the digastric muscle is another important anatomical landmark in parotid surgeries. The main trunk of the facial nerve is usually found superficial and medial to the posterior belly of the digastric muscle. This muscle serves as a consistent landmark to help in locating the facial nerve trunk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methods to identify the facial nerve trunk during parotid surgeries:

questions.text: Identify the type of joint marked in the image: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Saddle

 

  • The marked joint in the image is the incudo-malleolar joint, which is a type of saddle joint. This joint is located in the middle ear and involves the malleus and incus bones. The mnemonic "SBI" helps remember the types of joints in relation to the incus:
    • S for Saddle joint (incudo-malleolar joint)
    • B for Ball and socket joint (incudo-stapedial joint)
    • I for the Incus, positioned in front and behind the respective joints.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ball and socket: Incorrect. The ball and socket joint is found in the incudo-stapedial joint, not the incudo-malleolar joint.

 

Option C. Plane: Incorrect. The plane joint is not represented in the middle ear ossicles.

 

Option D. Gliding: Incorrect. Gliding joints are not present in the middle ear ossicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The incudo-malleolar joint is a saddle joint, an important anatomical feature in the middle ear.

questions.text: What anatomical feature separates the anterior two-thirds of the tongue from the posterior one-third? (AIIMS NOV  2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: c. Sulcus terminalis

 

Explanation:

 

 

The sulcus terminalis is a V-shaped groove on the surface of the tongue that demarcates the anterior oral two-thirds from the posterior pharyngeal one-third. This feature is critical because it not only divides the tongue into distinct anatomical regions but also corresponds to different developmental origins and nerve supplies. The anterior part of the tongue is primarily involved in taste and manipulation of food, while the posterior part is involved in swallowing and contains the lingual tonsil.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option a (Passavant’s ridge) is incorrect as it refers to a ridge formed by the contraction of muscles in the pharyngeal wall, not a feature of the tongue.
  • Option b (Circumvallate papillae) is incorrect; while these are located near the boundary of the anterior and posterior parts of the tongue, they do not themselves demarcate these regions.
  • Option d (Filiform papillae) is also incorrect as these are the most common type of papillae on the tongue's surface and cover the anterior two-thirds, providing no demarcation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sulcus terminalis is a key anatomical landmark on the tongue, dividing its anterior two-thirds, which handles taste and food manipulation, from the posterior one-third, associated with swallowing and immune response via the lingual tonsil.

questions.text: Identify the structure which is responsible for elevation and is supplied by the nerve emergency from the structure shown in the image? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Risorius

 

Explanation:

 

Risorius is supplied by the facial nerve, resulting in the marked elevation. The image depicts the floor of the fourth ventricle, as well as the facial colliculus.

 

 

The facial colliculus is a raised area on the floor of the fourth ventricle in the brainstem, and it is associated with the motor nucleus of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). The facial nerve is responsible for the motor innervation of the muscles of facial expression, including the risorius muscle, which is one of the muscles that can cause elevation of the corner of the mouth in smiling. Therefore, the structure that is supplied by the nerve causing this elevation would be the risorius muscle.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral rectus: Is an extraocular muscle that arises from the lateral part of the common tendinous ring. It is innervated by the abducens nerve.

 

Option B. Superior oblique: Is an extraocular muscle that arises from the body of the sphenoid. It is innervated by the trochlear nerve.

 

Option D. Levator palpebrae superioris: The levator palpebrae superioris muscle is supplied by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III). This muscle is responsible for raising the upper eyelid (levator means "elevator"), allowing you to open your eyes.

 

The oculomotor nerve also innervates several other muscles that control eye movement and pupil constriction, making it an important cranial nerve for eye function

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risorius muscle, responsible for pulling the corner of the mouth laterally and aiding in expressions like smiling, is innervated by the facial nerve.

questions.text:
A patient presents to you with fever, jaundice, and malaise. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the serology reports given below? (NEET PG 2023)

 

  • Anti-HBc (IgM): Positive
  • HBsAg: Positive
  • Anti-HBs: Negative
  • Anti-HCV antibodies: Negative
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acute hepatitis B

 

The serology results provide crucial information for diagnosing the type of hepatitis the patient has:

 

  1. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): Positive
    • This indicates an active hepatitis B infection, as HBsAg is a marker of infection.
  2. Anti-HBc (IgM) (Hepatitis B core antibody, IgM): Positive
    • The presence of IgM anti-HBc indicates a recent infection or acute hepatitis B. IgM is produced early in the infection and suggests that the infection is recent.
  3. Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): Negative
    • The absence of anti-HBs indicates that the patient has not resolved the infection or been vaccinated. In the context of acute infection, this is expected as the patient has not yet developed immunity.
  4. Anti-HCV antibodies: Negative
    • This indicates that the patient does not have hepatitis C.

 

Based on these results, the diagnosis is acute hepatitis B. The presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc are key indicators of an acute infection.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Acute hepatitis C: This is ruled out by the negative anti-HCV antibodies.

 

Option C. Chronic hepatitis B: Chronic hepatitis B is diagnosed when HBsAg persists for more than six months and is typically associated with IgG anti-HBc, not IgM.

 

Option D. Chronic hepatitis C: This is ruled out by the negative anti-HCV antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc in a patient with fever, jaundice, and malaise strongly indicates acute hepatitis B.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely tumor arising from the slide shown in the image?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenocarcinoma

 

The provided histopathological image shows multiple gland formations, which is characteristic of adenocarcinoma. Adenocarcinomas are malignant tumors that arise from glandular epithelial cells. The presence of glandular structures in the histological slide is a key indicator of this type of cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of carcinoma is characterized by the presence of keratin pearls and intercellular bridges, which are not seen in the provided image.

 

Option C. Lymphoma: Lymphomas are malignancies of the lymphoid tissue and do not typically show glandular patterns in histology.

 

Option D. Sarcoma: Sarcomas arise from mesenchymal cells and are characterized by spindle-shaped cells. They do not exhibit glandular formations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenocarcinoma is identified by the presence of glandular formations in histopathological slides.

questions.text: Match the following: (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

 1. Cocaine - b. White lady

 

  • Cocaine is known by various street names such as snuff, rock, crack, coke, snow, Cadillac, and white lady.

 

2. LSD - c. Purple wedge

 

  • LSD (Lysergic acid diethylamide) is referred to by names like acid, blotter acid, blue caps, blue dots, brown caps, crackers, Deeda, purple Owleys, purple wedges, The Beast, The Chief, The Ghost, The Hawk, and white lightning.

 

3. Abrus precatorius - d. Gunchi

 

  • Abrus precatorius, also known as Indian liquorice, prayer beads, crab's eye, weather plant, gulagunchi, ratti, and gunja, is a plant known for its toxic seeds.

 

4.  Capsaicin - a. Hunan hand

 

  • Capsaicin, the active component in chili peppers, is known to cause burning sensations on the skin, particularly the hands, leading to the term 'Hunan hand.'

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct matches are Cocaine with "White lady," LSD with "Purple wedge," Abrus precatorius with "Gunchi," and Capsaicin with "Hunan hand."

questions.text: Identify the histological structure shown in the image below. (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pancreatic islet cells

 

  • The pancreas has two main parts: the exocrine and endocrine pancreas.
  • The endocrine part of the pancreas is composed of islets of Langerhans, which are characterized by secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers and numerous fenestrated capillaries.
  • Each islet is surrounded by a delicate capsule and appears paler than the surrounding exocrine cells due to the presence of less rough endoplasmic reticulum.
  • The image provided depicts the histology of the pancreas.

 

 

Pancreatic Islet Cells (Islets of Langerhans): Scattered throughout the pancreas, these islets are endocrine clusters differing from the surrounding exocrine pancreatic tissue.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Alpha Cells: Produce glucagon which increases blood glucose levels.
  • Beta Cells: The most common islet cell, producing insulin which decreases blood glucose levels.
  • Delta Cells: Produce somatostatin, which regulates the other islet cells.
  • Gamma Cells (PP or F cells): Produce pancreatic polypeptide, which regulates some of the pancreatic exocrine and endocrine functions.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymph Node: Lymph nodes are small, bean-shaped structures found throughout the lymphatic system.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Capsule: A dense connective tissue covering.
  • Trabeculae: Extensions from the capsule that divide the node into compartments.
  • Cortex: Contains densely packed lymphocytes and has follicles with germinal centers.
  • Medulla: Central part containing medullary cords (lymphatic tissue) and medullary sinuses filled with lymph.
  • Hilum: The area where blood vessels and nerves enter and exit and where the efferent lymphatic vessels leave the node.

 

Option B. Glomerulus: A tuft of capillaries situated within Bowman's capsule in the nephron of the kidney.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Endothelial Cells: These line the inner surface of the capillaries.
  • Basement Membrane: Lies between the endothelial cells and the podocytes, playing a critical role in filtering the blood.
  • Podocytes: These are specialized epithelial cells that cover the outer surfaces of the glomerular capillaries. Their foot processes interdigitate and form filtration slits.
  • Mesangial Cells: Located between the capillary loops and provide structural support and phagocytic functions.

 

Option C. Spleen: The spleen is an intraperitoneal organ that filters blood and is involved in immune reactions.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Capsule: Dense connective tissue with smooth muscle cells.
  • Trabeculae: Extensions from the capsule containing blood vessels.
  • White Pulp: Lymphatic tissue arranged around arterioles (central arteries). It's involved in immune responses.
  • Red Pulp: Consists of splenic cords (reticular connective tissue with many blood-filled sinuses). It filters the blood of antigens, microorganisms, and defective or worn-out red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the causative agent associated with in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pure red cell aplasia

 

  • The provided picture displays the typical appearance of a slapped cheek  due to cutaneous vasodilatation, indicating a probable case of erythema infectiosum.
  • This condition is caused by the Parvovirus B19.
  • Parvovirus B19 is linked to pure red cell aplasia.

 

MANIFESTATIONS OF PARVOVIRUS B19

 

1. Fetus

  • Severe anemia (transient aplastic crises)
  • Pure red cell aplasia
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Spontaneous abortion

 

 

2. Children/adults

  • Fifth disease, erythema infectiosum, slapped cheek fever
  • 7−10-day incubation
  • Nonspecific “flu-like” symptoms followed by raised, indurated facial rash (Slapped cheek)

 

 

3. Adults

  • Rash and arthralgias (involves wrist most often) are due to immune complexes in the skin and joints.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gingivostomatitisis can be caused by Herpes virus.

 

Option C. Molluscum contagiosum is an infection caused by a poxvirus 

 

Option D. Kaposi sarcoma is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19, the causative agent of erythema infectiosum, is associated with pure red cell aplasia, particularly in individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders.

questions.text: According to the current biomedical waste management guidelines, which colored bin should be used for the disposal of blood bag? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Yellow bin 

 

  • Yellow Bin: Used for human and animal anatomical waste, soiled waste, expired or discarded medicines, chemical waste, and clinical lab waste.
  • This includes items such as body parts, blood bags, and items contaminated with body fluids.
  • The disposal methods typically involve incineration, plasma pyrolysis, deep burial, or chemical treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old construction worker presents with shoulder weakness and an inability to lift his arm sideways above the shoulder level. He reports no recent trauma but mentions a history of neck pain that radiates into his upper arm. Neurological examination reveals diminished strength in shoulder abduction. The physician suspects a nerve root involvement affecting the shoulder muscles. Which nerve root values are most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. C5-C6

 

Explanation:

 

The inability to abduct the arm is most commonly associated with a C5-C6 nerve root lesion, as these nerve roots contribute to the formation of the axillary nerve, which innervates the deltoid muscle. The deltoid muscle is the primary muscle responsible for shoulder abduction beyond the first 15 degrees. Damage to the C5-C6 nerve roots can impair the function of the deltoid muscle, leading to weakness or paralysis, making it difficult for the patient to abduct the arm.

 

Other Options:

 

A. C6-C7: While C6-C7 nerve roots are involved in the innervation of some shoulder and arm muscles, they do not primarily innervate the deltoid or contribute significantly to shoulder abduction. C6-C7 lesions are more associated with deficits in elbow flexion and wrist extension.

 

C. C8-T1: These nerve roots primarily contribute to the innervation of the intrinsic hand muscles and some forearm muscles. They are not involved in shoulder abduction and would not typically present with symptoms of deltoid weakness.

 

D. T1-T2: Nerve roots T1-T2 are primarily associated with the innervation of the hand and do not play a significant role in shoulder movement. Lesions at these levels would not affect shoulder abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The C5-C6 nerve roots are essential for shoulder abduction as they form the axillary nerve, which innervates the deltoid muscle. Damage to these nerve roots can lead to weakness or paralysis of the deltoid muscle, resulting in difficulty abducting the arm.

questions.text: Which of the following mood stabilizers causes hepatitis ? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Valproate

 

Valproate is known to cause hepatotoxicity, thus it is essential to monitor liver function tests regularly in patients taking valproate, especially during the initial months of therapy.

 

 

Educational Objective :

 

Valproate, a commonly used mood stabilizer in bipolar disorder, is associated hepatitis. Regular monitoring of liver function tests is crucial in patients on valproate therapy to detect and manage potential liver damage early.

choices.text: Regeneration is limited to the limbus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about corneal epithelium? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bowman's membrane regenerates.

 

The false statement about the corneal epithelium is B, stating that "Bowman's membrane regenerates." This is incorrect as Bowman's membrane is an acellular layer composed of collagen fibers and, once damaged, does not regenerate. The other statements regarding the corneal epithelium are true and align with the anatomical and functional characteristics of the cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Regeneration is limited to the limbus: This is true as limbal stem cells are key to the regeneration of the corneal epithelium.

 

Option C. Lined by stratified squamous epithelium: True, this describes the specific cell type forming the corneal epithelium.

 

Option D. Apical cells have microvilli: Also true, the microvilli increase the surface area for better adhesion of the tear film, enhancing eye lubrication and protection.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A pregnant lady with a history of recurrent abortions is now diagnosed to have antiphospholipid syndrome. What would be the best mode of treatment for her? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspirin + heparin

 

Explanation

 

Aspirin + heparin:

 

  • Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by recurrent pregnancy loss, thrombosis, and the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies.
  • The primary cause of pregnancy loss in APS is believed to be due to inhibition of trophoblast function and differentiation, which leads to placental dysfunction.
  • The best management approach for pregnant women with APS includes:
    • Low dose aspirin: Initiated as soon as pregnancy is confirmed. Aspirin helps by preventing platelet aggregation and improving blood flow to the placenta.
    • Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH): Started once fetal cardiac activity is detected. LMWH helps prevent blood clot formation, thus reducing the risk of thrombosis and improving pregnancy outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin only: While low-dose aspirin is beneficial, it is not sufficient alone for the prevention of complications in APS. The addition of heparin provides better protection against thrombosis and pregnancy loss.

 

Option C. Aspirin + heparin + steroids: Steroids are not routinely used in the management of APS during pregnancy due to their potential side effects and lack of evidence showing added benefit in preventing pregnancy loss when combined with aspirin and heparin.

 

Option D. Aspirin + steroids: Similar to the previous option, steroids are not recommended as part of the standard management for APS in pregnancy. The combination of aspirin and heparin is the preferred treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best management for pregnant women with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) to prevent recurrent pregnancy loss includes low-dose aspirin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

 

Ref: Page no 2907, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text:
Which of the following increase the risk of recurrence of febrile seizures? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Age < 1 year
  2. Temperature of 38-39°C
  3. Duration of fever < 24 h
  4. Duration of fever > 48 h
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3

 

The risk of recurrent febrile seizures is increased in children who are less than 1 year old, have a fever with a temperature between 38-39°C, and have a fever duration of less than 24 hours. Febrile seizures typically occur in children between the ages of 6 and 60 months and are generalized tonic-clonic seizures that occur in the setting of fever without any underlying intracranial infection or a previous history of unprovoked seizures.

 

Risk Factors:

 

1. Age < 1 year: Younger age increases the likelihood of recurrent febrile seizures.

 

2. Temperature of 38-39°C: Lower fever temperatures (38-39°C) are associated with a higher risk of recurrence.

 

3. Duration of fever < 24 h: A shorter duration of fever before the onset of seizures is associated with an increased risk of recurrence.

 

Other Information:

 

  • Minor risk factors for recurrence include male gender, attending daycare, having complex febrile seizures, a family history of febrile seizures, and lower serum sodium levels at presentation.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Duration of fever > 48 hours: A duration of fever greater than 48 hours is not considered a risk factor for febrile seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risk of recurrent febrile seizures is increased in children under 1 year of age, with fever temperatures between 38-39°C, and fever lasting less than 24 hours.

questions.text: All are ocular manifestations of dengue except: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cataract

 

  • Cataract is not a common ocular manifestation of dengue infection.
  • Dengue infection can have various manifestations in different organ systems, primarily characterized by inflammation and bleeding.
  • Until recently, eye involvement was not recognized as a common feature of dengue infection, apart from retro-orbital pain.
  • The potential pathogenic mechanisms for dengue-related eye involvement may include direct viral effects on the eye, immune-mediated vasculitis, and/or a variety of secondary effects related to dengue-induced vascular leakage and hemostatic derangements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subconjunctival hemorrhage: Common in dengue due to increased fragility of blood vessels and thrombocytopenia.

 

Option C. Uveitis: While less common, uveitis can occur in dengue fever as part of a systemic immune response to the infection.

 

Option D. Retinal hemorrhage: This is a direct consequence of the hemorrhagic tendency in dengue fever, related to thrombocytopenia and vascular fragility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ocular manifestations of dengue:

 

  • Typically, patients complain of painless visual impairment within 1 week from illness onset, often around the time of the platelet nadir.
  • Conjunctival injection and subconjunctival hemorrhage.
  • Complications such as retinal hemorrhage, retinal edema, macular ischemia, macular edema, vitreous hemorrhage, vitritis, and optic neuritis or papillitis.
  • Depending on the severity of the ocular lesion, gradual improvement in vision occurs over several weeks, although in rare cases permanent visual impairment may result.

choices.text: History of similar illness in the past

questions.text: A man from Chhattisgarh presented with a gradual onset of muscle weakness and spasms in his legs. Upon examination, he exhibited a specific loss of motor function. What inquiries should be made to gather the most relevant medical history from this patient? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) History of diet

 

  • The clinical presentation suggests that the patient may have neurolathyrism, which is caused by the excessive consumption of Lathyrus sativus or Khesari dal.
  • To confirm the diagnosis, it is important to obtain the patient's dietary history.
  • Neurolathyrism is a paralytic condition caused by the consumption of Lathyrus sativus or Khesari dal, which is common in certain regions of India such as Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, and Bihar.
  • The disease mainly affects the nervous system, causing gradual spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. It primarily affects males between the ages of 15 and 45 years and progresses through several stages.
  • The toxin responsible for the disease is BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine), which is water-soluble and can be removed from the pulses by soaking them in hot water and discarding the water.
  • Large-scale detoxification can be achieved by parboiling the crop, or by overnight soaking in lime water followed by boiling.
  • Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can help prevent and treat lathyrism.
  • In India, the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act prohibits the use of Lathyrus sativus in any form (whole/split/flour).

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a young man who has presented with painful lesions, as depicted in the image below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes Zoster

 

  • The above image shows confluent, red, vesicular lesions in a single dermatome which is associated with severe pain; hence the most likely diagnosis here would be herpes zoster or shingles.
  • Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution.
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection, but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  • Painful zoster infections in adults
  • Facial zoster at any age
  • Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum contagiosum: This is a viral infection of the skin that causes small, pearly, or flesh-coloured bumps. The lesions are typically umbilicated, meaning they have a small indentation or dimple at the centre as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option C. Herpes Simplex: It presents as grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, usually around the lips or genital region as shown in the image below. It does not follow a dermatomal pattern.

 

 

Option D. Lymphangioma circumscriptum: This condition presents as vesicles filled with lymphatic fluid as shown in the image below. It typically does not have the painful, dermatomal distribution seen in herpes zoster.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ability to recognize Herpes Zoster by its characteristic painful, vesicular rash in a unilateral dermatomal distribution.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page nos 4.13, 25.27-25.28, 109.36, 128.2,

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

questions.text: Mw vaccine is extracted from which of the following bacteria? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) M. indicus pranii

 

Mw vaccine is extracted from M. indicus pranii

 

The Mycobacterium w (M.w) vaccine is a heat-killed suspension derived from a non-pathogenic mycobacterium: mycobacterium indicus pranii. As an immunotherapy, M.w is used against leprosy; the compound also shares antigens with M. tuberculosis. Its use has shown clinical improvement, rapid bacterial clearance, and enhanced immune responses to Mycobacterium leprae antigens.

 

Administration: 0.1 ml intradermal. It is divided into two equal doses and given on both arms. Booster doses are injected only on one arm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. M. welchii: This bacterium is known for causing gas gangrene and is not associated with the Mw vaccine.

 

Option C. M. leprae: This bacterium is the causative agent of leprosy, but the Mw vaccine is not derived from M. leprae itself.

 

Option D. M. bovis: This bacterium causes tuberculosis in cattle and can also infect humans, but it is not the source of the Mw vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mw vaccine is extracted from Mycobacterium indicus pranii and is used in the immunotherapy of leprosy, enhancing immune responses and promoting rapid bacterial clearance.

choices.text: Glutamine replaced by asparagine
Glutamine replaced by alanine
Glutamine replaced by glutamate
Glutamine replaced by arginine

questions.text: Which of the following would have no effect on the function of the protein product? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glutamine replaced by asparagine

 

Amino acid replacement is a change from one amino acid to a different amino acid in a protein due to point mutation in the corresponding DNA sequence. It is caused by nonsynonymous missense mutation which changes the codon sequence to code other amino acid instead of the original.

 

Usually, amino acids are thus classified into two types:

 

  1. Conservative replacement - an amino acid is exchanged into another that has similar properties. This type of replacement is expected to rarely result in dysfunction in the corresponding protein.

For example, leucine and isoleucine are both aliphatic, branched hydrophobes. Similarly, aspartic acid and glutamic acid are both small, negatively charged residues.

 

  1. Radical replacement - an amino acid is exchanged into another with different properties. This can lead to changes in protein structure or function, which can cause potentially lead to changes in phenotype, sometimes pathogenic.

 

Example - Sickle cell anemia, due to a mutation in beta globin where at position 6 glutamic acid (negatively charged) is exchanged with valine (not charged).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glutamine replaced by alanine: Glutamine is a polar, uncharged amino acid, while alanine is a nonpolar, aliphatic amino acid. This radical replacement could affect the protein's structure or function.

 

Option C. Glutamine replaced by glutamate: Glutamine is a polar, uncharged amino acid, while glutamate is a polar, negatively charged amino acid. Although they are similar in size, the difference in charge makes this a radical replacement, potentially affecting protein function.

 

Option D. Glutamine replaced by arginine: Glutamine is a polar, uncharged amino acid, while arginine is a polar, positively charged amino acid. This radical replacement could significantly alter the protein's structure or function.

 

Educational Objective

 

Conservative replacements, such as replacing glutamine with asparagine, typically do not affect the protein's function because the substituted amino acids have similar properties. Radical replacements, involving amino acids with different properties, are more likely to impact protein function.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a radiological finding in a patient with left heart failure? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Focal oligemia

 

Focal oligemia, also known as the Westermark sign, is a radiological finding indicative of pulmonary embolism, not heart failure. It represents a regional reduction in lung vascularity and is seen on chest radiographs as an area of decreased blood flow and enhanced clarity due to vascular obstruction from a clot.

 

Other Options:

 

Radiological Findings in Left Heart Failure:

 

Option A. Kerley B lines: These are thin linear opacities caused by interstitial edema, especially near the lung bases, and are commonly associated with congestive heart failure.

 

Option C. Increased venous blood in lung: Also known as pulmonary venous hypertension, this finding is due to increased pressure in the pulmonary veins that results from left heart failure.

 

Option D. Change in upper lobe circulation: This refers to the redistribution of blood flow to the upper lobes, a classic sign of pulmonary venous hypertension seen in left heart failure.

 

Further Stages of Left Heart Failure on CXR:

 

  1. Stage 1 (PCWP 13-18 mmHg): Cardiomegaly, redistribution of pulmonary vessels, broad vascular pedicle.
