  2. Stage 2 (PCWP 18-25 mmHg): Kerley B lines and peribronchial cuffing indicating interstitial edema.
  3. Stage 3 (PCWP > 25 mmHg): Alveolar edema leading to consolidation and pleural effusion.

 

Educational Objective:


In patients with suspected heart failure, radiological findings such as Kerley B lines, increased pulmonary venous pressure, and altered upper lobe circulation are indicative. Focal oligemia, however, suggests a differential diagnosis of pulmonary embolism and should prompt further investigation for this condition rather than heart failure.

 

 

Reference - Radiology assistant/ CXR in heart failure

questions.text: Which one of the following is not involved in iron metabolism? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transthyretin

 

Transthyretin is not involved in iron metabolism. It transports thyroxine.

 

Hepcidin, a 25-amino-acid (aa) peptide, is the principal regulator of iron absorption and its distribution to tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceruloplasmin: Functions as a ferroxidase, converting Fe2+ (ferrous iron) to Fe3+ (ferric iron), which is essential for iron binding to transferrin for transport.

 

Option B. Hepcidin: A 25-amino-acid peptide that is the principal regulator of iron absorption and its distribution to tissues. It inhibits iron release from enterocytes, macrophages, and hepatocytes by binding to ferroportin, leading to its degradation.

 

Option D. Transferrin: The main iron transport protein in the blood. It binds and transports iron to various tissues, including the bone marrow for erythropoiesis and the liver for storage.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: The iliopubic tract attaches directly to the iliac spines.
The iliopubic tract is a thickening of the transversalis fascia.
The iliopubic tract runs anterior to the inguinal ligament.
The iliopubic tract has no association with the fascia of the iliacus muscle.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with groin pain that worsens with activity. On physical examination, the physician notes tenderness along the inguinal region but no palpable hernia. Imaging is ordered to further assess the anatomy of the groin, revealing a structure deep to the inguinal ligament, which plays a role in the reinforcement of the abdominal wall. The physician explains the significance of this structure in relation to hernia formation. Which of the following statements is true about the iliopubic tract?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. The iliopubic tract is a thickening of the transversalis fascia.

 

Explanation:

 

The iliopubic tract is a condensation of the transversalis fascia located immediately posterior to the inguinal ligament. It extends superolaterally from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and arches across the front of the femoral sheath, contributing to the structural integrity of the inguinal region. Medially, it attaches to the pubic tubercle and pectineal line, while laterally, its fibers fan out and blend with the fascia iliaca. This connection supports the abdominal wall and helps to reinforce the area against herniation, especially in relation to the femoral canal.

 

Other Options

 

A. The iliopubic tract attaches directly to the iliac spines: This statement is incorrect because the iliopubic tract does not have direct attachment to the iliac spines. Instead, it runs superolaterally from the anterior superior iliac spine but does not attach directly to the spines, spreading its fibers within the fascia.

 

C. The iliopubic tract runs anterior to the inguinal ligament: The iliopubic tract actually lies posterior to the inguinal ligament, not anterior to it. This positioning provides support from beneath, reinforcing the inguinal area.

 

D. The iliopubic tract has no association with the fascia of the iliacus muscle: This is incorrect as the fibers of the iliopubic tract fan out and blend with the fascia of the iliacus muscle, known as the fascia iliaca, forming an important connection between the abdominal wall and pelvic sidewall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The iliopubic tract is a thickening of the transversalis fascia that runs posterior to the inguinal ligament and blends laterally with the fascia of the iliacus muscle. It plays a crucial role in reinforcing the anterior abdominal wall and providing structural support to the inguinal and femoral regions, helping to prevent herniation.

questions.text: A person undergoing Anti PD1 immunotherapy (Nivolumab) presents with itching, eczema, and hives-like rashes. Upon histopathological analysis, a blister beneath the outer skin layer is observed. The direct immunofluorescence assessment of the affected areas indicates the presence of Linear C3 and IgG along the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bullous pemphigoid

 

BULLOUS PEMPHIGOID

 

  • Immunobullous disease with a sub epidermal split
  • IgG is the autoantibody deposited
  • Target protein: Hemi desmosomes
  • Target antigens: BPAG 2 > 1
  • No acantholysis
    • Clinical Features: Involves primary lesions (Tense pruritic bullae on Erythematous skin or normal skin) and secondary lesions (Itchy Bullae → Erosions due to scratching).
    • Sites: Trunk, abdomen, flexural aspects of extremities, 10-30% of patients have oral erosions.

 

 

  • Investigation:

 

1. Tzanck smear: Presence of eosinophils and Absence of acantholytic cells.

 

2. Histopathology:

 

 

3. Direct Immunofluorescence: show IgG, C3 linear deposits along Basement Membrane Zone.

 

 

  • Treatment: Topical steroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus Vulgaris: Involves intraepidermal blisters and suprabasal acantholysis (separation of skin cells), which are not described in the provided scenario. Direct Immunofluorescence would typically show intercellular deposits, not linear along the basement membrane.

 

Option C. Dermatitis Herpetiformis: Characterized by intensely itchy blisters and associated with gluten sensitivity. Direct Immunofluorescence shows granular IgA deposits at the tips of dermal papillae, not the linear deposition along the basement membrane.

 

Option D. Pemphigus Foliaceous: Presents with superficial (epidermal) blisters that do not affect the deeper layers of the skin. The immunofluorescence pattern would not show the linear deposition along the basement membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bullous Pemphigoid in patients undergoing immunotherapy is critical due to the potential severity of the condition and the need for prompt and effective management to reduce symptoms and prevent complications. Monitoring for new or worsening symptoms in patients on immunotherapy is essential to catch such reactions early.

choices.text: Breech identified for the first-time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery
Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency CS is available
Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labor
Should be done by a skilled obstetrician

questions.text: A woman in labour presented to the ER. A vaginal breech delivery was planned for her. What statement regarding the management is false? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Breech identified for the first-time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery

 

Explanation:

 

The statement that breech presentation identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery is false.

 

Breech identified for the first-time during delivery is not automatically a contraindication for a vaginal breech delivery. It is crucial to assess the situation carefully, considering the skill of the obstetrician and the facilities available, but it does not universally rule out the possibility of a vaginal breech delivery.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency CS is available: This is correct because the presence of a facility for emergency cesarean section is essential for managing unexpected complications during a breech delivery.

 

Option C. Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labor: This is correct because continuous fetal heart rate monitoring is crucial to detect any signs of fetal distress during a breech delivery.

 

Option D. Should be done by a skilled obstetrician: This is correct as vaginal breech deliveries should be performed by an experienced and skilled obstetrician to manage the potential risks and complications effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breech presentation identified for the first-time during delivery is not an automatic contraindication for vaginal delivery, provided other criteria are met and facilities are available.

 

Ref: Page no 449, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of dilation and curettage in sequence? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Serial dilation
  2. Curettage
  3. Uterine sound
  4. Assessment of uterine size and direction
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4-3-1-2

 

The correct sequence for performing a dilation and curettage (D&C) is as follows:

 

4. Assessment of uterine size and direction : Before any procedure, the first step is to assess the size and direction of the uterus to plan the approach and ensure that any interventions are appropriately targeted.

 

3. Uterine sound : The next step involves using a uterine sound to measure the depth and assess the shape and orientation of the uterine cavity. This helps to guide the subsequent dilation process.

 

1. Serial dilation : After assessing the uterus, serial dilation of the cervix is performed using progressively larger dilators to allow access to the uterine cavity.

 

2. Curettage : Finally, curettage is performed to remove the contents of the uterine cavity, which completes the D&C procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for dilation and curettage (D&C) is to first assess the uterus, perform uterine sounding, then serial dilation, and finally proceed with curettage.

 

Ref: Page no 585, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: The mother of a 12-year-old girl was worried that her daughter is shorter when compared with her classmates. On examination, the child had a webbed neck, low hairline, and shield chest. A provisional diagnosis of Turner's syndrome was made. Which of the following is a likely finding to be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bilateral small streak ovaries

 

The likely finding seen in a patient with Turner syndrome is bilateral small streak ovaries.

 

Turner syndrome results from complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome. It is characterized by hypogonadism in phenotypic females. It is the most common sex chromosome abnormality in females. Three types of karyotypic abnormalities are seen

 

  • Missing an entire X chromosome - this results in a 45X0 karyotype.
  • Structural abnormalities of the X chromosomes
  • Mosaics - they will have 45X along with one or more karyotypically normal or abnormal cell types. Examples are 45X/46XX, 45X/46XY, 45X/47XXX, 45×/46X, ¡(X)(q10).

 

Important features associated with Turner's syndrome:

 

 

  • Short stature
  • Webbing of neck
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Cubitus valgus
  • Streak ovaries
  • Infertility, amenorrhea
  • Peripheral lymphedema at birth
  • Low posterior hairline
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Pigmented nevi
  • Coarctation of aorta

 

Normal secondary sex characteristics do not develop during puberty. The genitalia remain infantile, breast development is inadequate, and pubic hair is scarce. In adults, short stature and amenorrhea are especially important in establishing the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic dissection: While Turner syndrome is associated with cardiovascular abnormalities, such as coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve, aortic dissection is less common in children and typically occurs in adults with significant aortic disease.

 

Option B. Subluxation of lens: Subluxation of the lens is a feature of Marfan syndrome, not Turner syndrome.

 

Option C. Mitral valve prolapse: Mitral valve prolapse is more commonly associated with connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Turner syndrome is more characteristically associated with left-sided heart defects like coarctation of the aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by features such as short stature, webbed neck, shield chest, and streak ovaries, leading to primary ovarian insufficiency, infertility, and amenorrhea. The diagnosis is confirmed by karyotyping, and the most likely finding in Turner syndrome patients is bilateral small streak ovaries.

questions.text: True regarding the lesion of the structure marked by 5 the arrow is: (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Wrist drop

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in the image is the radial nerve demonstrated in the cubital fossa. A lesion of the radial nerve leads to a wrist drop. Injury to the radial nerve leads to paralysis of the extensor muscles of the wrist and fingers. This results in an inability to extend the wrist and fingers actively, leading to the characteristic "wrist drop" appearance. The hand hangs flaccidly with the fingers flexed, and the person cannot extend them

 

 

Anterior view of the right cubital fossa:

 

The structures marked in the given image are:

 

  1. Branch of the median nerve to the brachialis muscle
  2. Biceps brachii muscle
  3. Brachialis muscle
  4. Lateral cutaneous nerve of fore arm
  5. Superficial branch of the radial nerve
  6. Brachioradialis muscle
  7. Flexor carpi ulnaris muscle
  8. Pronator teres muscle
  9. Brachial artery
  10. Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm
  11. Median nerve.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ape thumb deformity: This deformity is primarily associated with the median nerve lesion. It refers to an inability to oppose or flex the thumb due to weakness or paralysis of the thenar muscles (especially the opponens pollicis), which are innervated by the median nerve. This results in a flattened thenar eminence, giving the thumb an appearance reminiscent of an ape's thumb.

 

Option B. Claw hand: Claw hand, or "clawing" of the fingers, usually results from a combined ulnar and median nerve lesion. It is characterized by hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and flexion at the interphalangeal (IP) joints. It can also result from a high ulnar nerve lesion on its own. The claw hand deformity is not a typical consequence of radial nerve injury.

 

Option C. Claudication: Claudication refers to pain, cramping, or fatigue in muscles, typically the calves, during walking or exercise. It's a symptom of peripheral arterial disease, where there's reduced blood flow to the legs. This is not related to radial nerve injury.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of chest pain shooting to the neck and interscapular region. X-ray shows widened mediastinum. BP is 110/90 mmHg in the right upper limb and 160/100 mmHg in the left upper limb. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute aortic dissection

 

  • Patient with sudden-onset severe chest pain, with a difference in blood pressure between the two limbs, and a widened mediastinum on x-ray suggests a diagnosis of acute aortic dissection.
  • AORTIC DISSECTION is tear in intima of aorta

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS): ACS includes conditions such as myocardial infarction and unstable angina. These conditions typically present with chest pain but do not usually cause blood pressure discrepancies between limbs or a widened mediastinum.

 

Option B. Acute Pulmonary Embolism: Pulmonary embolism presents with sudden onset dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and signs of right heart strain. It does not typically present with blood pressure discrepancies between limbs or a widened mediastinum.

 

Option D. Esophageal Rupture: Esophageal rupture can present with severe chest pain, subcutaneous emphysema, and signs of sepsis. It does not typically present with blood pressure discrepancies between limbs. It may cause mediastinal widening but would more likely present with other signs such as subcutaneous emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The classic presentation of acute aortic dissection includes sudden severe chest pain radiating to the neck and back, a discrepancy in blood pressure between the limbs, and a widened mediastinum on chest X-ray.
  • Immediate imaging with a CT thoracic angiogram and lowering blood pressure are crucial steps in management.

questions.text: A tall 10-year-old boy presents with Sexual Maturity Rating 5 and hyperpigmentation. His BP is 150/100 mm Hg. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency

 

The presentation of a tall 10-year-old boy with a Sexual Maturity Rating (SMR) of 5 and hypertension (BP 150/100 mm Hg) indicates precocious puberty. The SMR of 5 typically signifies full sexual maturity, which is unusual for a 10-year-old and suggests precocious puberty.

 

Hyperpigmentation is likely due to elevated ACTH levels, which can occur in congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). The key to the diagnosis is understanding the enzyme deficiencies that lead to CAH and their associated symptoms.

 

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency leads to increased production of 11-deoxycorticosterone, a mineralocorticoid that causes hypertension due to salt retention. This condition also results in excess androgen production, leading to precocious puberty in boys and virilization in girls.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 21β-Hydroxylase deficiency: This is the most common cause of CAH but is typically associated with salt-wasting, not hypertension. It results in increased androgen production leading to virilization and ambiguous genitalia in females, and precocious puberty in males.

 

Option C. 17β-Hydroxylase deficiency: This deficiency is characterized by hypertension and hypokalemia but does not usually cause hyperpigmentation or precocious puberty. It often results in underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Option D. SCC (side-chain cleavage) deficiency: This enzyme deficiency leads to a severe form of CAH with salt-wasting and adrenal insufficiency but is not typically associated with hypertension or hyperpigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency in congenital adrenal hyperplasia causes hypertension due to salt retention and precocious puberty due to excess androgen production.

questions.text: A bus conductor presents with dilated, tortuous veins of 4 mm in the foot. What is the stage of clinical classification according to CEAP (Clinical-etiology-anatomy-pathophysiology for chronic venous disorders)? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C2

 

Explanation:

 

The CEAP classification system for chronic venous disorders categorizes the severity of venous disease based on clinical signs, etiology, anatomy, and pathophysiology. In this system, the "C" (Clinical) classification is particularly useful for describing the visible and palpable signs of venous disease.

  • C0: No visible or palpable signs of venous disease.
  • C1: Telangiectasias or reticular veins.
  • C2: Varicose veins. This stage is characterized by dilated, tortuous veins that are generally more than 3 mm in diameter, such as the 4 mm veins described in the patient's case.
  • C3: Edema related to venous disease.

 

Given the description of dilated, tortuous veins of 4 mm, the patient's condition corresponds to C2 in the CEAP classification, indicating the presence of varicose veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C0: C0 indicates no visible or palpable signs of venous disease, which does not apply to this patient who has visible varicose veins.

 

Option B. C1: C1 indicates the presence of telangiectasias or reticular veins, which are smaller than 3 mm in diameter. This stage does not describe the 4 mm varicose veins observed in this patient.

 

Option D. C3: C3 is used to classify edema related to chronic venous disorders. This does not match the presentation of dilated, tortuous veins without mentioned edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of dilated, tortuous veins larger than 3 mm, such as the 4 mm veins observed in the patient's foot, corresponds to stage C2 in the CEAP classification system for chronic venous disorders, indicating varicose veins.

choices.text: Synovial pivot joint
Ball and socket joint

questions.text: A 28-year-old male athlete presents to the clinic complaining of pain and weakness in his forearm, particularly during rotational movements such as pronation and supination. He reports that the symptoms began after a recent weightlifting session where he felt a sudden strain in his arm. Physical examination reveals tenderness along the length of the forearm with limited range of motion, particularly during twisting movements. The physician suspects an injury involving the structures that connect the radius and ulna. Which type of joint is the middle radioulnar joint classified as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Fibrous joint (syndesmosis)

 

Explanation:

 

The radius and ulna are connected by three joints: the proximal (superior) radioulnar joint, the middle radioulnar joint, and the distal (inferior) radioulnar joint. The middle radioulnar joint is classified as a fibrous joint known as a syndesmosis, where the bones are connected by dense fibrous tissues—the interosseous membrane and the oblique cord. The interosseous membrane is a broad, thin collagenous sheet running distomedially between the interosseous borders of the radius and ulna, providing significant stability and allowing for controlled movement of the forearm during pronation and supination. The oblique cord, extending from the radial tuberosity to the lateral side of the ulnar tuberosity, also contributes to this stabilizing structure. Unlike the proximal and distal radioulnar joints, which are uniaxial synovial pivot joints allowing rotational movements, the middle radioulnar joint does not have a joint cavity and primarily functions to hold the bones together.

 

Other Options

 

A. Synovial pivot joint: The proximal and distal radioulnar joints are classified as synovial pivot joints, which allow rotational movement around a single axis. These joints facilitate pronation and supination of the forearm, but they differ structurally from the middle radioulnar joint, which is a syndesmosis.

 

B. Cartilaginous joint: Cartilaginous joints involve bones connected by cartilage, such as synchondroses and symphyses, which allow limited movement. Examples include the pubic symphysis and intervertebral discs. This type does not fit the structure of the middle radioulnar joint.

 

D. Ball and socket joint: Ball and socket joints, such as those found in the shoulder and hip, allow for a wide range of movements in multiple directions. They consist of a spherical head fitting into a cup-like socket, which is not characteristic of the middle radioulnar joint’s fibrous connection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint (syndesmosis) connecting the radius and ulna via the interosseous membrane and oblique cord, providing forearm stability and controlled movement during pronation and supination. Unlike synovial pivot joints, it lacks a joint cavity and primarily functions to maintain the structural integrity of the forearm.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in heart failure?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trimetazidine

 

Trimetazidine is not used in heart failure because it is primarily a metabolic modulator. It partially inhibits the beta-oxidation of fatty acids, which results in shifting the metabolism of heart muscles from fatty acids to glucose. This shift requires less oxygen, making trimetazidine beneficial for patients with angina pectoris. However, it does not have a role in the management of heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker that is used in the management of chronic heart failure. Beta-blockers are contraindicated in acute heart failure but can be beneficial in chronic heart failure when started at a low dose and gradually increased to avoid decompensation. The beta-blockers commonly used in heart failure include carvedilol, metoprolol, and bisoprolol.

 

Option C. Sacubitril: Sacubitril is an NEP (neutral endopeptidase) inhibitor, which prevents the breakdown of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP). By inhibiting NEP, sacubitril increases BNP levels, leading to natriuresis and vasodilation, which are beneficial effects in chronic heart failure (CHF). Therefore, sacubitril is used in the treatment of CHF.

 

Option D. Nesiritide: Nesiritide is a recombinant form of BNP and is administered through the subcutaneous route. It helps to induce natriuresis and vasodilation, thus can be used in the treatment of heart failure.

 

Educational objective:

 

Trimetazidine, although beneficial for angina pectoris due to its metabolic modulation properties, is not used in the treatment of heart failure.

 

Note - Beta blockers are contraindicated in acute heart failure, but they can be used in chronic heart failure. Beta blockers should be started at low dose, dose should be increased gradually to prevent decompensation.

 

Beta blockers used are – Carvedilol, metoprolol and bisoprolol.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/ 599, 600

questions.text: What is the approximate age of a person in whom the medial end of the clavicle is fused and also the sternum is completely fused? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. >25 years

 

Approximate age for the given person with fused medial end of clavicle and completely fused sternum is most likely >25 years.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Thoracoscore? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Complication of Surgery

 

This is not a component of Thoracoscore. While complications of surgery can impact outcomes, they are not a predefined parameter in the Thoracoscore risk model.

 

The complication of surgery is not a component of Thoracoscore.

 

Thoracoscore is a risk model used to predict the probability of death within 30 days following thoracic surgery. The model takes into account the following nine parameters:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Performance status: This is a component of Thoracoscore. Poorer performance status is associated with a higher risk.

 

Option C. ASA grading: This is a component of Thoracoscore. The ASA score is used to assess the physical status and associated risk of patients undergoing surgery.

 

Option D. Priority of surgery: This is a component of Thoracoscore. The urgency of the surgery (elective vs. emergent) affects the risk of postoperative complications and mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thoracoscore is a predictive risk model for mortality within 30 days following thoracic surgery. It includes parameters such as age, sex, performance status, dyspnea score, ASA score, cardiovascular comorbidity, surgical procedure extent, cancer status, and urgency of surgery, but does not include the complication of surgery as a predefined parameter.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and was started on first-line antitubercular drugs. Which of the following drug acts by inhibiting the synthesis of the marked layer shown by arrow in the image?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Isoniazid

 

Isoniazid is activated by Catalase Peroxidase and it acts by blocking the mycolic acid synthesis. It is a bactericidal drug that is effective against both intracellular and extracellular bacteria that are actively replicating.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rifampicin: It is the most bactericidal drug, that is effective against intra as well as extracellular bacteria. It acts by blocking RNA polymerase.


Option C. Pyrazinamide: It is also bactericidal, that is effective mainly against intracellular bacteria. It acts by blocking fatty acid synthase.


Option D. Ethambutol: It is a bacteriostatic 1st line anti-tubercular drug that acts against both intra and extracellular bacteria by blocking arabinosyl transferase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isoniazid acts by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid, a critical component of the mycobacterial cell wall, making it an effective first-line treatment for tuberculosis. The other first-line drugs have different mechanisms of action, such as inhibiting RNA polymerase (rifampicin), blocking fatty acid synthase (pyrazinamide), and inhibiting arabinosyl transferase (ethambutol).

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presented in OPD with complaints of fatigue and weakness. Investigations revealed the following as shown below. The peripheral smear is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

Hb – 5 g%

 

MCH – 24

 

MCV – Low

 

TLC – 11000 /µL

 

Platelets – 5,00,000 /cubic mm

 

Normal values:

 

  • Mean cell volume (MCV): 90 +/- 8 fL
  • Mean cell Hb (MCH): 30 +/- 3 pg
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Iron-deficiency anemia

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of microcytic hypochromic anemia for which the most common cause is Iron Deficiency Anemia.

 

Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by:

 

  • Low serum ferritin: Reflects low iron stores.
  • Low serum iron: Indicates a lack of available iron.
  • High TIBC (Total Iron Binding Capacity): Reflects the body’s increased capacity to bind iron, which happens when iron levels are low.
  • Low transferrin saturation: Reflects low iron availability relative to the binding capacity.

 

These findings together with the low MCV, low MCH, low Hb and compensatory increase in the platelets strongly suggest iron deficiency anemia rather than other conditions.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Megaloblastic anemia: Typically presents with macrocytic anemia (high MCV), which is not the case here. Also, MCH would generally be elevated in megaloblastic anemia.

 

Option C. Thalassemia major: This condition would also present with microcytic anemia, but it typically does not show such severe hypochromia or the thrombocytosis seen in this case. Additionally, the Mentzer index (MCV/RBC count) is typically less than 13 in thalassemia trait, not in severe iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option D. Essential thrombocytosis: While this condition does present with an elevated platelet count, it does not typically present with the microcytic, hypochromic anemia seen in iron deficiency anemia. The primary abnormality in essential thrombocytosis is the elevated platelet count, without the severe anemia observed here.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the appropriate technique to measure the placement of a nasogastric tube? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) From the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum.

 

This is the correct method. The nasogastric tube length is usually measured by estimating the distance from the tip of the nose, past the ear lobule (or the earlobe), and down to the xiphisternum (the point where the sternum meets the costal margin), also known as N-E-X rule. This method ensures that the tube is long enough to pass through the esophagus and reach the stomach without being too long to cause complications or too short to not be effective.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

To determine the appropriate length of a nasogastric tube (also known as Ryle's tube) used for treating intestinal obstruction or providing nutritional support, the NEX method is commonly used, which involves measuring from the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum. The approximate length to be inserted is around 55 cm. The preferred position for inserting the Ryle's tube is in a sitting position with the neck slightly flexed.

 

The proper positioning of the tube can be confirmed through auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air or by an abdominal radiograph. The ideal placement for an NG tube used for suction is within the stomach to avoid damage to the duodenum. In contrast, an NG feeding tube should be placed post-pyloric to reduce the risk of aspiration.

 

Indications for NG tube usage include gastric decompression in intestinal obstruction, aspiration of gastric fluid, nutritional support, and medication administration. However, some absolute contraindications to NG tube insertion include severe midface trauma and recent nasal surgery.

 

A tray of specialized instruments is used for nasogastric tube insertion, including a lubricating jelly, an NG tube, a syringe, and gloves, among others.

choices.text: Superior & medial quadrant has more tissue
Axillary tail of Spence crosses anterior axillary fold
Nipple is located at 4th intercostal space in most of the females

questions.text: True statement regarding the breast (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Axillary tail of Spence crosses anterior axillary fold

 

The axillary tail of Spence is an extension of the breast tissue that extends into the axilla (armpit area). It passes through the anterior axillary fold, which is a region near the front of the underarm. This anatomical feature is important for surgical considerations, particularly in breast surgeries and examinations for breast cancer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior & medial quadrant has more tissue: This statement is incorrect. The superior and medial quadrant of the breast does not have more tissue compared to other quadrants. The distribution of tissue in the breast is such that no specific quadrant is known to universally have more tissue in every individual.

 

Option B. 10 lobules are present: This statement is incorrect. The human breast typically contains around 15-20 lobules, not just 10. These lobules are responsible for the production of milk and are connected to ducts that lead to the nipple.

 

Option D. Nipple is located at 4th intercostal space in most of the females: While the nipple is located at the level of the 4th intercostal space in males. In females, its position can vary among individuals due to the pendulous nature of the breast. Factors such as age, breast size, and body position can influence the exact location of the nipple.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The axillary tail of Spence crosses the anterior axillary fold, which is an important anatomical detail relevant in breast examinations and surgeries.
